Problem:
Consider the Laplace transform of a function \\( g(t) \\) given by \\( L[g(t)] = \\int_{0}^{\\infty} e^{-st}g(t) dt \\). We analyze how the convolution of another function, \\( h(t) \\), impacts g(t) in terms of their transforms. Assume both functions are well-behaved and their transforms exist.

If an additional transformation, represented by the function \\( f(s) = s^2 \\), is applied to the Laplace transform of \\( g(t) \\) before convolution, will the final Laplace Transform of the convolution still be a mere product of the transformed \\( g(t) \\) and \\( h(t) \\)?
Explanation: The additional transformation of \\( g(t) \\) by \\( f(s) \\) before convolution modifies the original transform. Consequently, the product rule for Laplace Transforms under convolution fails as the Laplace Transform of g(t) no longer remains simply \\( L[g(t)] \\), but becomes \\( s^2 \\times L[g(t)] \\).
